title: Homemade Custom Auxiliary Input Panel for Flight Simulator
overview: This was one of my first embedded projects, aimed at improving flight simulator immersion by adding a custom auxiliary input device.
The goal was to control more simulator parameters (e.g., flaps, propeller pitch, mixture) than a typical joystick or keyboard allowed.
I designed a compact control panel based on a SparkFun Pro Micro board, using five analog slide potentiometers and a button matrix to provide extended input capabilities.
highlights: Selected and wired five analog slide potentiometers for continuous control of simulator parameters.
Implemented a button matrix to allow additional discrete inputs without using many GPIO pins.
Wrote Arduino firmware that presented the panel as a USB HID joystick for plug-and-play compatibility with flight sims.
Hand-soldered all components on a perfboard and tested integration with flight simulator game.
results: The panel successfully extended flight sim control capabilities with five additional analog axes and multiple buttons.
It provided a much more immersive experience, especially for controlling aircraft systems during simulation.
Potential future improvements include adding a proper enclosure, motorized potentiometers, and additional switches to increase the number of input channels.
